One fayre Par-royall hath our Iland bred</br>Whereof one is a live and two are dead</br>Sidney the Prince of prose and sweet conceit</br>Spenser of numbers and Heroick Ryme</br>Injurious Fate did both their lives defeate</br>For war and want slew both before their time</br>Now tho they dead lodge in a princely roome</br>One wants a verse, the other wants a toome.

Camden thou livest alone of all the three</br>For Roman stile and Englishe historye</br>Englande made them thou makest Englande knowen</br>So well art thou the prince of all the payre</br>Sithence thou hast an Englande of thine owne</br>Lesse welthy, but as fruitfull and more fayre</br>Nor is thine Englande moated with the maine</br>But doth our seas, and firmed lands contain

And scornes the waves wherwith our Ile is pent</br>Spreadinge it self through the wilde worldes extent.</br>Lesse needs it feare the swellinge of a brooke</br>Whose lowly chanell feeds on privat lake</br>That can the prowder ocean over looke</br>And all the streames that thence their courses take.</br>Long may both Englands live and livinge raigne</br>In spightt of Envy thine and ours of Spaine.

While in ours in thine may thou in ours abide</br>Thine ages honour and thy cuntries pride</br>And if perchance th' ingratefull age denies</br>To grace thy death with toombe and scrolled verse</br>Each village, church and house their want supplies</br>Each stone thy grave, each letter is thy verse</br>And if all those should be with thine outwore</br>Each streame should grave thy name uppon his shore.</br>
